Lore: ISB attache to the \ul Executor\ul0. Detention Officer. Political Liaison for COMPNOR. Responsible for all prisoner transfers. Fiercely loyal to the Emperor's New Order.
Gametext: Adds 1 to power of anything he pilots. When deployed, may take an ISB agent here into hand. Once per turn, if you just drew an ISB agent for battle destiny anywhere, may take that card into hand to cancel and re-draw that destiny.
IsPulled: Blizzard 4\par I Can't Shake Him! (V)

Lore: The carbonite froze more than just Han's body.
Gametext: Deploy on table. My Favorite Decoration may not be placed out of play. At same site as Jabba's Prize, opponent's characters deploy +1 and your Force drains are +1. While Jabba's Prize with Scum and Villainy, your total power in all battles is +3. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Re-released in Virtual Set 12 "Tweak Set". Original text:\par Deploy on table. Opponent's characters deploy +1 to same site as Jabba's Prize. When you capture a character, opponent loses 1 Force. Your Force drains at same battleground site as Jabba's Prize are +1. My Favorite Decoration may not be placed out of play. (Immune to Alter.)

Characteristics: \b Sakiyan\b0, \b Black Sun agent\b0, \b assassin\b0, \b bounty hunter\b0
Lore: Male Sakiyan, a race often employed as assassins. \b Bounty hunter\b0. Incredible infrared, peripheral vision. Has excellent aural and olfactory senses. Often tracks by scent.
Gametext: Power, defense value, and forfeit +1 for each [Dark Side Force icon] icon here.  Your total ability may not be reduced at same site. Your Force drains here may not be canceled by [Reflections III] Leia.
IsPulled: Double Back

Lore: Capital starships have emergency escape pods. Equipped with food, water, flares, medpacs, hunting blaster and tracking beacon. (R2-D2 deactivated this one's beacon).
Gametext: Use 1 Force to take into hand from Reserve Deck (reshuffle) a dejarik or holosite. OR Cancel a Force drain at a holosite. OR If opponent is about to place your character out of play, place that character in your Lost Pile instead.
Information: BG-J38 adds 2 to the destiny of each of your holograms and dejariks drawn for battle destiny or weapon destiny.
Pulls: Grimtaash\par Houjix\par K'lor'slug\par K'lor'slug (V)\par Mantellian Savrip\par Dejarik Hologameboard
Cancels: A Force drain at a holosite.

Lore: When Vader's forces impose the New Order upon a region, Rebel resources and lifelines are quickly eliminated.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Lost if your non-Imperial character (or starship) on table. Unless you occupy fewer locations than opponent: if you win a battle, retrieve an Imperial; and, during battle, may take an Imperial just drawn for destiny into hand to cancel and redraw that destiny. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Original card: Imperial Domination\par Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par \par Errata February 2020. Original title: Imperial Domination (V)\par -----\par (note that the pre-reset domination also triggered for initiating battle)\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), but harder to use due to the fact that you can only play with Imperials if you use this card. In addition to offering some solid character retrieval, this card also does a decent job of causing your opponent to spread out quickly so that they can suspend the gametext of this card. The battle destiny limiting may seem like a bad idea for a battling deck, but in reality there aren't a lot of ways for all-Imperial decks to get multiple battle destiny anyway, and this way you can use characters like Lord Vader and have the immunity to attrition be worth more than if you had to worry about your opponent drawing 5 battle destiny and basically making your immunity worthless. Another reason this is a solid battling card is because if you draw battle or weapon destiny and accidentally flip a character, you can take it into hand and try again, allowing you to play with more characters than you would normally be able to get away with while still maintaining the integrity of the deck's destiny.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Wow, great minds think alike. This is my #5 as well. I really like the versatility that this card brings to an Imperial deck and think that as stronger Imperials are created this card will see more and more play.\par Armaedes made a bunch of good points about this card above, but there were a few things I also wanted to add. First, two copies of this can be played for maximum use, which means twice as many benefits heading your way. It may be overkill in many instances, but if it is worth it, you'll never go without characters ever again. Secondly, there are some creative ways for you to use it as a cycling machine. DDM had an interesting Hunt Down that used a lone Womp Rat to constantly draw against Vader so that he could draw needed Imperials into hand. I also don't think that limited destiny draws as a bad thing- with you constantly weeding out low destiny characters your 2 destinies should be stronger than your opponent's. This is also yet another great battle winning effect that works with many of the other cards on this list.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par No argument here, and the two-copies thing is an important point I forgot to mention. I have seen this card used effectively in Hunt Down, BHBM, ISB, Ralltiir, and even some Combat Readiness (V) decks. Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's good because it rewards you for battling by giving you more characters to battle with. Unlike Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's far more deck-specific, but getting back characters is always a good thing.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Elegant sword of pure energy. "This is the weapon of a Jedi Knight. Not as clumsy or as random as a blaster." A lightsaber can be dangerous to an unskilled user.
Gametext: Deploy on Mace. May add 1 to Force drain where present. Mace may add 1 to his duel total. May target a character or creature for free. Draw two destiny. Target hit, and its forfeit = 0, if total destiny > defense value.
IsPulled: Gift Of The Mentor
MatchingWeapon: Mace Windu\par Mace Windu (V)\par Mace Windu, Jedi Master

Lore: Senior \b Jedi Council member\b0  who maintains rigorous adherence to the Code. Sent Qui-Gon to Naboo to accompany the Queen and learn more about the mysterious "dark warrior."
Gametext: During battle, Mace may 'swing' one lightsaber twice. Fetts may not add battle destiny draws here. Immune to attrition < 6 (< 8 if with a Dark Jedi).
Information: Also available as a full-card virtual slip that may be used on Mace Windu, Jedi Master, as of October 2020\par \par Original concept by Zane Thorp\par \par Mace Windu personas are:\par \par Mace Windu\par Mace Windu (V)\par Mace Windu, Jedi Master
IsPulled: Speak With The Jedi Council\par Tatooine: City Outskirts
Combo: Mace Windu (V) + Are You Brain Dead?!

Lore: \b Dejarik\b0  of a Ng'ok war beast. Foul temper gives rise to bad feelings. Has razor-sharp retractable claws. Used in many systems to frighten off potential attackers.
Gametext: Deploy on table. If your character, starship, or vehicle in battle is about to be lost before the damage segment, it is instead lost at end of battle (if forfeited, forfeit for 0). (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par \par Errata December 2015. Original text:\par Deploy on table. If your character in battle is about to be lost before the damage segment, it is instead lost at end of battle (if forfeited, forfeit for 0). (Immune to Alter.)\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par One of my pet peeves, briefly touched upon under #1, is character removal. The Dark Side is rife with popular ways to get rid of your heroes such as Dr. Evazan, Dark Strike, and Choke Vader. K'lor Slug (and Molator for the DS) helps you avoid painful beatdowns due to sudden losses of power and destiny draws. While this is more like IMI in that it helps your battles hold their effectiveness, the second part of the text goes very well with immunity mains. Your mains can get out at their normal cost, which greatly speeds up the time it takes to get them into play by a turn or more.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Again, I find this less of an offensive aid than a defensive aid, and more of a battle-hindering card than anything else. The dark side's character removal is a big way dark wins battles, so in my opinion taking this away makes effective battling more challenging. I really like this card - I think it is a necessary component of the game - but I'm not sure I would classify it as a battling aid.
IsPulled: Masterful Move\par Masterful Move & Endor Occupation\par Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans\par Surface Defense (V)

CardName: Imperial Entanglements/No One To Stop Us This Time

For remainder of game, you may not deploy Sandwhirl, Jabba's Palace sites, non-Imperial characters, non-Imperial starships, or systems. Opponent’s characters require +1 Force to move from Tatooine sites using their landspeed. During your draw phase, you may retrieve one trooper. Flip this card if opponent controls more Tatooine sites than you.

Lore: Smuggler and Rebel starships use black market armor plating and deflector shields to withstand enemy fire. Expensive but life-saving modifications.

Lore: Imperial Security Bureau (ISB) officer assigned to brief Tarkin. Also ordered to ensure absolute loyalty to the Emperor. \b Leader\b0. Will stop at nothing to fulfill the Emperor's will.
Gametext: Adds 1 to power of anything he pilots (2 if any capital starship). When deployed, may activate up to X Force (limit 4), where X = number of ISB agents on table. While aboard a starship, its power may not be reduced by opponent.

Lore: Gantry officer charged with maintaining magnetic field, atmosphere and security in Death Star docking bay. After mission on Ralltiir, paranoid about infiltration by Rebel spies.
Gametext: Adds 1 to power of anything he pilots. When deployed (or leaves table), may draw top card of Reserve Deck or Used Pile. During battle, attrition against you is -1 for each ISB agent here (limit -3). Your spies here (unless Undercover) are immune to Double Agent.

Lore: The youngest handmaiden, Yane stayed behind on Naboo while Amidala pleaded her case to the Galactic Senate. \b Musician.\b0
Gametext: Whenever opponent deploys a character to same or adjacent site, may activate 1 Force. While with Amidala, forfeit +1, and once per turn may peek at the top card of your Force Pile and Reserve Deck; return one card to each deck or pile.
IsPulled: My Loyal Bodyguard

Lore: Actions borne of the love for one's planet can heavily outweigh those generated from simple battle orders.
Gametext: If We Have A Plan on table, deploy on table. Imperials deploy +1 to Theed Palace Throne Room and, while you occupy that site, you may ignore your Objective's location deployment restrictions. Once per game, may take into hand from Reserve Deck (reshuffle) an [Episode 1] system and/or a [Theed Palace] leader. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Original card: Security Control\par \par Original concept by Scott Lingrell
IsPulled: Don't Tread On Me (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: Modified S-5 security blasters can be used for a wide array of purposes.
Gametext: During your deploy phase, use X Force (minimum 1) to relocate X of your characters at an interior Theed Palace site to Theed Place Throne Room. (Immune to Sense.) OR If opponent occupies your location, peek at top two cards of your Reserve Deck and take one into hand.
Information: Original concept by Pat Johnson
IsPulled: Naboo: Theed Palace Hallway\par Naboo: Theed Palace Hallway (V)

Lore: "It's a good bet the Empire knows we're here."
Gametext: USED: Play a Defensive Shield from under your Starting Effect. OR Target opponent's just-deployed [Maintenance] card. Target may not battle (or allow opponent to deploy from Reserve Deck (reshuffle) cards) for remainder of turn. (Immune to Sense.) LOST: Cancel Trample (unless targeting an Undercover spy).
Counterpart: Turn It Off! Turn It Off! (V)

DarkSideText: Your Ugnaughts deploy free aboard starships here. If you control, all your Ugnaughts on table are forfeit +2.

Gametext: Once per game, may take into hand from Reserve Deck (reshuffle) [Virtual Set 1] Ascension Guns. You may move to here using landspeed for free.    While We Have A Plan on table, your Force icons here are canceled.

Gametext: Permanent pilot is (*]Green Leader, who provides ability of 2. Adds one battle destiny with a Rebel snub fighter. During battle, may cancel immunity to attrition of one starship here; this A-wing is 'hit'.
Information: Original card: A-wing Cannon\par \par Errata January 2019. Original text:\par Permanent pilot is *Green Leader, who provides ability of 2. Adds one battle destiny with a Rebel snub fighter. During battle, may cancel immunity to attrition of any starship here; this A-wing is 'hit'.\par \par A snub fighter is any A-wing, B-wing, X-wing, Y-wing or Z-95

Lore: \b Enclosed\b0.
Gametext: May add 1 pilot. Permanent pilot is (*]Dash, who provides ability of 3. During battle, if with another T-47 and about to draw a battle destiny, may draw two and choose one. Immune to attrition < 4.
Information: Original card: Rebel Snowspeeder\par \par Errata March 2019. Original title:\par Dash In Rogue 10
IsPulled: Combined Fleet Action\par Commander Luke Skywalker (V)\par Lone Rogue
Combo: This card gains immune to attrition < 6 from Echo Base Garrison
Rules: Draw X Choose Y\par When a card instructs you to draw x destiny and choose y, perform the following steps:\par Step 1) Draw a destiny. This draw can be modified, canceled, reset, or otherwise responded to normally just after it is drawn; however, after being drawn, unless canceled, it remains an Unresolved Destiny Draw and is not yet placed in Used Pile. The draw is considered a weapon destiny, battle destiny, etc. where appropriate, and counts against any applicable limits. If a limit prevents a player from drawing more than x destinies, they instead draw a number of destinies equal to the limit. Repeat this step until x destinies have been drawn. \par Step 2) Once x destines have been drawn, choose a destiny from among the Unresolved Destiny Draws and resolve it normally. Repeat this step until an appropriate number of destinies have been chosen as specified by y. \par Step 3) Place any remaining unresolved draws in used pile (unless otherwise instructed) in the order they were drawn (if possible).\par \par \par Note that this means any just action responding to a just drawn destiny in a Draw X Choose Y situation must do so when it is DRAWN (in step 1) and not when it is CHOSEN (in step 2). Once the process has moved on to Step 2, with the player who drew choosing which destinies to use, the draws can no longer be responded to as just drawn. \par \par Also worth noting is that all destinies drawn with a Draw X Choose Y card count against applicable limits or other cards that count the number of destinies, even if they are not chosen. That is to say, limits count the number of destinies drawn, not the number of destinies chosen. To illustrate, here are a few examples: \par \par Example 1: Dash In Rogue 12 (applicable text: During battle, if with another T-47 and about to draw a battle destiny, may draw two and choose one.) is in a battle with another T-47, and the Light Side player is limited to ONE battle destiny. In this situation Dash In Rogue 12's 'draw 2 and choose 1' text cannot be used because both destinies drawn with Dash count as battle destiny draws. \par \par Example 2: If a similar situation played out, but the Light Side player was limited 2 battle destinies instead of 1, the Light Side player using Dash In Rogue 12's text on 1 destiny would reach the limit of two battle destinies on its own, because even though only one such destiny would be chosen, two destinies were still drawn. If the light side player had a way to add a battle destiny in this example, they would be better off NOT using Dash In Rogue 12's text and simply drawing 2 normal destinies, because using Dash In Rogue 12's text on the first destiny would cause them to reach the limit of 2, preventing them from drawing the added battle destiny after. \par \par Example 3: Dash In Rogue 12 is in a battle with Commander Luke Skywalker v piloting Rogue 1 (so that Luke draws 2 battle destiny if unable to otherwise). Luke's text will be usable because when it checks how many destinies Light Side is scheduled to draw at the beginning of the power segment, it will only see 1. (Luke's text only counts one destiny able to be drawn because Dash In Rogue 12's text has not triggered yet - it is only usable when the Light Side is about to draw a battle destiny) While the Light Side may theoretically use Dash In Rogue 12's text to draw 2 and choose 1 on the first destiny drawn, they would no longer be able to draw the 2nd destiny with Luke's text, because players may never combine multiple destiny drawing to draw more than the 'if unable to otherwise' text allows (see "Battle Destiny - Draws X Battle Destiny If Unable To Otherwise" on AR page 6-6). In this case, drawing 2 and choosing 1 on the first destiny and attempting to draw the second would mean the Light Side would be drawing 3 battle destinies, which would be prevented by 'if unable to otherwise' rules. If the first destiny with Luke's text is drawn normally, the Light Side player may not use Dash In Rogue 12's text on the second destiny from Luke's text, because again, that would result in the Light Side player drawing 3 destinies and would be prevented. In short, like example 2, the Light Side player would be better off simply drawing 2 normal battle destinies rather than using Dash In Rogue 12's text in this situation.

Lore: Due to constant Imperial pursuit, Alliance engineers became adept at constructing new facilities quickly.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn, may use 2 Force to deploy from Reserve Deck (reshufffle) a battleground system. Your non-unique starfighters apply their deployment modifiers at any location. Once per turn, if you just Force drained at a battleground system, may draw top card of Reserve Deck.
Pulls: Anoat\par Anoat (V)\par Aquaris\par Bespin\par Bothawui\par Chandrila\par Corellia\par Corulag\par Coruscant\par Coruscant (EP1)\par Endor\par Endor (V)\par Hoth\par Jakku\par Kamino\par Kashyyyk\par Kessel\par Kiffex\par Kirdo III\par Malastare\par Mon Calamari\par Naboo\par Nar Shaddaa\par Ord Mantell\par Raithal\par Ralltiir\par Roche\par Scarif\par Sullust\par Takodana\par Tatooine\par Tatooine (EP1)\par Tibrin\par Yavin 4\par Yavin 4 (V)
